newsitem.title: FRANCE: Council of Europe urges caution on EMU policy.
newsitem.headline: Council of Europe urges caution on EMU policy.

text.p: Parliamentarians from the Council of Europe's 40 member states called on Thursday for caution in pursuing European Monetary Union in the European Union, the Council said on Tuesday.

The European Council assembly welcomed the potential benefits of EMU, such as currency stability and a common economic policy, but warned that it should not hamper European Union enlargement, it said in a statement.
EMU would lead to a loss of national sovereignty and EU countries should assess the impact of EMU on their national economies and how to make it democratically accountable.
The reporter for the assembly's report on EMU, Mikko Elo of Finland, said EMU was the EU's key project and if it failed, it would be a political failure.

Assembly speakers underlined the need for democracy and transparency and said a future European Central Bank should be democratically accountable. A social dimension should be included in the move to economic union.
They also raised concerns that there would be a widening gap between rich and poor.
A single currency would affect the whole of Europe and not just the EU countries, economic affairs committee chairman Terry Davis said.

"It is vitally important to ensure that EU attempts to stabilise the European economy do not stabilise European society as a result of cuts in welfare spending in order to satisfy the Maastricht criteria," he said.
